byline.contributor: Kitty Bennett and Karen Yourish contributed research.

abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigation, over span of just two years, has sharply increased its use of stings in terrorism cases, employing agents and informants to pose as jihadist and sympathizers while investigating Americans suspected of helping Islamic State; agency says undercover operations are necessary in world where social media provides suspects with increased anonymity, but some critics have raised concerns that these operations have little public oversight and can lead to entrapment.

headline.print_headline: Once Last Resort, F.B.I. Stings Become Common in ISIS Fight
headline.main: F.B.I. Steps Up Use of Stings in ISIS Cases

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

snippet: A sharp rise in the number of undercover operations, once considered a last resort, has come with little public or congressional scrutiny.
